node.title: What one comedy-of-errors date taught me about my disability and disclosure
node.description: When Caleb Rixon suffered a catastrophic stroke aged 24, his life and career as a musical performer was turned upside down. While the path back to dating has been full of potholes, he's learnt a few things along the way.
node.content:
["It's my 24th birthday, and my partner of the past four years has surprised me with a night in a fancy-pants hotel in Sydney's Darling Harbour.", "I'm sitting on the edge of a fancy bed, in a fancy hotel room, wearing a fancy robe and snapping selfies.", "Sipping champagne, I'm revelling in the feeling that I've got it all.", "After travelling to New York City to perform in a new musical, I graduated from the prestigious Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts.", "", "
Caleb's stage career was taking off when his life took a sudden and unexpected turn.(Supplied)
", "Securing a performing arts agent, I performed in the musical 'Altar Boyz' and landed a role in the Australian tour of Chicago: The Musical.", "I love my career and my partner, an incredible guy with a huge heart who is a significant part of my life.", "", "
Caleb had his sights set on a career on the stage.
", "He is also an upcoming performer who shares my lofty goals of performing on global stages; singing, dancing and moving the masses.", "So, we train hard and nurture our bodies to do the tricks we need to perform.", "
In an instant, everything changes
", "Three days after my birthday, I'm working out at the gym. Five minutes into a pump class I feel a smash behind my left eye, and my eye pops out. It's as if someone with a baseball bat takes a swing to the back of my head.", "I spring up to catch my eye as it falls out of its socket, but I catch nothing. I feel around my eye socket, and it's still in place. \"OK, something's wrong. You've overdone it.\"", "", "
A gym workout spiralled out of control when a range of sudden and bewildering symptoms struck.(Unsplash: Danielle Cerullo)
", "I need to see what's wrong, so I make my way through the bench-pressing bodies to find a mirror, expecting to see my shattered eye \u2014\u00a0but nothing.", "It looks normal, but I suddenly collapse to the gym hallway floor.", "A parade of gym shoes begin nervously shuffling and surrounding me.", "\"Oh my God,\" I think.", "4 Minutes\u00a0by Madonna and Justin Timberlake continues to pump through the gym, and the voices fussing around me are starting to sound distant.", "My left side spasms out of control. I'm going to throw up. My heart is in my throat. Something is seriously wrong.\u00a0", "Luckily, a nurse who was working out at the time identifies the situation, calls triple-0 and the paramedics arrive quickly.", "I retell the story of my eye-popping out and not being able to swallow to the paramedic.", "He looks at my partner and asks:\u00a0\"Does he normally speak like this?\"", "On playback, I hear my slurred speech and eventually, the footlights of my life go dim and the curtain closes.", "Whilst the curtain is down and my theatre is dark, my incredible community of stagehands, support crew, and health professionals work together to save my life.", "", "
Caleb faced a long path to recovery after suffering a catastrophic stroke.(Supplied)
", "When I open my eyes, I peer through a kaleidoscope and see mum sitting at the foot of my bed.", "The room is quiet with only a faint echo of Darth Vader sounds coming from machinery surrounding me.", "She looks comfortable, as if she's been sitting there a long time (five weeks in fact).", "I call out to her, but nothing comes out. I'm moving my lips, but I can't make any sound.\u00a0", "There were two ruptures in the lining of my brain due to a congenital abnormality called a Dural Arteriovenous Malformation (DAVM) leading to bleeding into my brain stem and impact to my cerebellum, causing a grade 5 subarachnoid haemorrhage.", "Extraventricular drains were placed into my skull to relieve the pressure on my brain and life-saving surgery was performed involving a partial craniotomy and resection of the DAVM.", "", "
Significant medical interventions were needed to save Caleb's life.(Supplied)
", "Put simply, my friends and family would tell you that a rare tangle of arteries and veins have exploded in the back of my head \u2014\u00a0resulting in me having a massive stroke.", "The stroke has paralysed my vocal cord and my ability to swallow.", "I can't sit or stand up and can only see a twisted double image due to damage to my optic nerve.", "I've gone from being a budding actor, singer and dancer to a baby unable to walk, talk or swallow, with permanent double vision and vertigo.", "My relationship with my partner eventually breaks down due to the pressures brought on by my recovery process, rehab, and efforts towards rebuilding my life.", "We went from being two ambitious, perfectly matched people to patient and caregiver, eventually leading to the dissolution of the relationship.", "
A leap back into the dating game
", "Over time, I want to feel young and desirable again.", "But how do I meet someone? I can't see in nightclubs, I'm permanently dizzy, strobe lights are a nightmare and I can't drink because I can't balance.\u00a0", "The last thing I'm going to do is wear my eyepatch and take my walking stick into a club.", "I've lost my identity, agency and all my confidence with intimacy.", "", "
Caleb's stroke caused serious damage to his optic nerve.
", "My clinical psych advises I create an online dating profile so I can be in control of how much I disclose and when, but when writing my profile, I stall.", "Rehab consumes my life, I don't feel I have much else to share right now \u2014\u00a0and a little tip, writing on a gay dating profile that your interests and hobbies include \"learning to swallow\" can be misconstrued \u2014\u00a0and so, I chose not to disclose any of my condition.", "Eventually, I get a match with a cute Kiwi dude, and I suggest we meet in a cafe in Prahran.", "The minute I meet him I internally panic, judging him on his good looks and preppy charm, I assume I'm not good enough for him and he'll end the date before it's even begun.", "Surprisingly, he buys my \"I'm cool, calm and capable\" elevator pitch, which strategically leaves out any mention of my stroke.", "", "
Caleb Rixon says his experience on a date triggered reflection on when to disclose a disability to a potential partner.(Supplied)
", "But the problem is, he buys it so much he doesn't want the date to end.\u00a0", "He wants to walk back to his place in St Kilda, from South Yarra,\u00a0about 4 kilometres away.", "Side note: I haven't walked more than 400 meters since my stroke.", "He wants to walk, talk and make eye contact,\u00a0things that all \"cool, calm and capable\" men can do, but I have to concentrate on the pavement and stop every 100m pretending to \"window shop\" just to steady myself.", "", "
Dashing across an inner-Melbourne road was among the hurdles Caleb faced during his date.(ABC News: James Hancock)
", "He spots his friends and dashes across Dandenong Road to say hello, so I awkwardly follow him, doing my best 'Dandenong Dash', trying to stay involved in the conversation.", "I try to appear as 'normal' as possible.", "We get back to his place and everything I do to hide my situation only makes things worse.", "After our walk, my feet are covered in blisters because I'm wearing tight shoes (purchased one size too small to help me balance), so I ask to take them off.", "He hears \"I wanna get comfortable\".", "
'I had a stroke'
", "My mouth has insidiously been pooling with saliva and I can no longer swallow nor coordinate 'regular-looking human breathing', so I casually ask for a drink.", "I clock him assessing the scenario:", "He raises his eyebrows and I'm thinking \"...f***\".", "With my nystagmus (vertigo) in full flight, I discreetly do a controlled landing onto the couch and he jumps in beside me holding two glasses of water.", "He hands me a glass, then he goes in for a pash. I freeze. He pulls back and we hold each other's gaze for an uncomfortably long time.", "I take a breath and tell him: \"I had a stroke.\"", "Immediately, he gives me some space and keeps a hand on my knee to assure me of feeling safe.", "He discloses a relatable story about trauma in his life. \"I would never have known you'd had a stroke. How has it affected you?\" he asks.", "I'm so afraid of being vulnerable, I deflect, as if the stroke hasn't impacted me as significantly as it has.", "", "
Caleb now works to help people who have experienced traumatic strokes share their story and heal.(Supplied)
", "After assessing the situation, he tries to lighten the mood.", "\"How about we grab a quick bite for dinner, get a DVD, and come back here and open up a bottle of wine?\"", "So I put my tight shoes back on and we head to the local vegetarian restaurant. With my blistered feet, I'm barely keeping up with him, when suddenly he makes a dash to catch the lights at the pedestrian crossing.", "I attempt to keep up, but he's so fast that I stumble, hesitate and stop.", "As he gets to the other side of the road, he looks back at me and his face falls.", "\"Ah, you can't...\"", "\"Run. No, I can't run very well. I can't run.\"", "We blankly stare at each other, searching for something to say.", "Quickly, I move us on to grab our \"quick bite\" to try and avoid the awkwardness.", "For anyone with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), there's no such thing as a \"quick bite\".", "I use large mouthfuls of water to wash down small mouthfuls of food and maintain the conversation to keep up appearances.", "After 15 minutes his plate is empty. He sees mine is barely touched.", "\"You eat like a bird,\" he says.", "I'm embarrassed and nervous he will judge me on my lack of swallowing know-how.", "I tell him I'm not hungry and offer him the rest of my meal, which he scoffs down.", "My tummy rumbles in retaliation.\u00a0", "We walk to the DVD store, and he suggests I pick the movie.", "By this late in the day my eyes are fatigued, and focusing is difficult, but I don't want him to know so I pretend to be excited and pick the first cover that pops out at me.", "I have no idea what it is other than it's red. He takes it from my hand and raises his eyebrows.", "\"Good choice.\"\u00a0Turns out, I've chosen a homoerotic reading of Shakespeare's 'Othello'.", "We get back to his place and settle in for the movie. Gay Othello finally finishes. He says he wants to watch a second movie and asks if I want to watch 'Beaches'.", "\"Sure!\" I say enthusiastically.", "\"F***!\" I scream internally.", "I'm so fatigued that I can't converge a single image, so for five hours I watch him out of the corner of my eye, taking his lead and laughing when he laughs, to look like I'm following the films.\u00a0", "Finally the night is coming to an end. I'm exhausted, hungry, my feet are killing me and I'm so self conscious that I can't unfreeze or be truthful about the extent of what's going on for me.", "He sees nothing is going to happen and decides to turn in for the night.", "He gives me a sincere and wholesome hug and I make my way home.", "
Next time, I'm doing it my way
", "Despite my comedy of errors, I feel the date has been a huge success.", "I'm so proud of myself for overcoming the obstacles and getting through it, that I want to do it again. But on my terms.\u00a0", "", "
Caleb plans to approach the next date he goes on differently.(Supplied)
", "Over the next few days, I fantasise about how much better our next date will be; staging it at my house, in the safe surroundings of familiar four walls.", "Kinda like a giddy 16-year-old school kid, I was experiencing some sort of second adolescence.", "However, this wasn't the same place where he was at, and he gently decided not to pursue the relationship.\u00a0", "It hurt and it was hard,\u00a0but it was right.\u00a0We were at different places in our lives.", "Since then, I can't help but wonder how might it have been if I'd let myself be vulnerable and honest.\u00a0", "Vulnerable in front of him and honest with both of us about what I had been through.\u00a0", "Maybe it would have been different If I'd pressed pause on our dishonest date, taken a courageous, deep breath, looked him in the eye \u2014\u00a0double vision and all \u2014\u00a0and simply chose to disclose more of my truth.", "Caleb Rixon is the founder of the genyus network, which works to increase mental health and individual capacity for young survivors of stroke and other trauma."]
